Literature Review: Active colloids have garnered significant attention in recent years due to their unique ability to propel themselves through viscous fluids by consuming fuel from their surroundings. This phenomenon is often modeled using numerical and theoretical approaches to understand the underlying mechanisms and their applications in various fields. In this review, we will discuss the current state of modeling active colloids, focusing on the generic model of an active Brownian particle, the squirmer model, and the explicit modeling of self-generated fluid flow and full hydrodynamic-chemical coupling. We will also explore recent advances in modeling active colloids in complex environments, microrheology in active baths, active colloidal engines, and adaptive responses using machine learning techniques.
